Dr. Hayward: Thank you very much, Emma. Ladies
and gentlemen, it's a real delight to be back

5.text:
in Hillsdale again - a part of normal America
- you know, this week is a heavy travel week:

10.text:
I'm going to be at Yale University on Friday,
where I'm going to do my best to point out

16.text:
to them that they have a lot of changes they
need to make if they want to be known as the

20.text:
Hillsdale of the northeast. And, as a few
of you know, I recently finished ... I should

31.text:
maybe say, I recently survived a year as an
inmate at the University of Colorado at Boulder,

39.text:
which is Berkeley with snow, right? In a fit
of madness, they decided they wanted to hire

46.text:
a conservative to come try out for a year
... or, actually, three years was the idea,

52.text:
and I said I would try it for a year and no
longer.

54.text:
Boulder, of course ... their idea of a conservative
at Boulder is a Trotskyite, right? And so,

63.text:
after I got there, I thought, this'll be interesting,
I'm kind of a gonzo guy, I've been at Berkeley,

67.text:
how hard could this be? And I had a lot of
fun with them, because I get invited to all

73.text:
kinds of liberal audiences who wanted to see
this exotic zoo animal in their midst. And

79.text:
the first thing I would tell them is, "You
know, you have it all wrong. I'm going to

82.text:
let you in on a little secret. I shouldn't,
but I will. Conservatives love Boulder." And

87.text:
they would say, "Really?" And we love Boulder
especially for the "green belt" that's around

94.text:
it. The environmentalists, 30 or 40 years
ago, put in a green belt to control growth

98.text:
and preserve their quality of life, and I
said, "The green belt is the best feature

101.text:
of Boulder. I wish they had one in Berkeley.
I mean, the green belt makes the quarantine

106.text:
so much easier to enforce. You see, it's easy
to have our Tea Party picket line set up around

113.text:
the perimeter, and, you know, when a liberal's
trying to escape, out in the real world, we

116.text:
round them up, hand them a bag of fresh, organic
kale, and send them back into the village.

120.text:
And, you guys, just stay there. It's perfectly
fine with us if you wreck Boulder, and Madison,

124.text:
and Cambridge, and Berkeley, if the rest of
America is relatively safer. And then, usually,

130.text:
things went downhill from there.
I had a great time, actually. I was actually

136.text:
embedded, for a semester, in the environmental
studies department. And, boy, that was fun.

142.text:
I'm going to begin, tonight, with my conclusion.
And then show you how I got to this conclusion.

149.text:
My conclusion is that, decades from now, I
think historians are likely to look back on

155.text:
the hysteria over climate change today the
way we, today, look back on prohibition: as

162.text:
a comic misadventure that shows the harsh
limits of political enthusiasm directed against

167.text:
basic facts of nature and society. However
- and here's the complicating part - whether

174.text:
we'll avoid committing the folly of embracing
the energy equivalent of prohibition is still

180.text:
undecided. I'm thinking that we won't, but
it may be a close-run thing, for a very simple

188.text:
and elemental reason, and that's the environmental
movement, which is deeply authoritarian at

193.text:
its core, has an unquenchable will to power
that cannot be satisfied and will not be denied.

199.text:
And, so, the fate of this is in the balance,
as Al Gore might have said in a different

206.text:
way, and, as I say, we can't tell, yet, whether
this will be looked back upon as a comic misadventure

212.text:
or a tragic misadventure.
Now, the formal title of my speech this evening

218.text:
is, "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to
Global Warming." And I love this title. I

225.text:
wasn't sure, though, whether Tim Caspar and
Doug Jeffrey weren't being mischievous, a

228.text:
little bit, thinking that my, you know, double
chin ... I was starting to look like Zero

234.text:
Mostel - you need to be a little older to
get that reference, I know. But I do like

238.text:
the title. But, actually, three funny things
have happened on the way to global warming.

245.text:
Three of them. First, the warming stopped.
Imagine that.

251.text:
Second, the policy agenda of the "climatistas,"
as I call them ... or, an even better term

258.text:
for the climate crusaders is, "Thermageddonites."
I didn't think of that. That's Briton's Lord

265.text:
Monckton came up with that, and I think that
one's really good. But the policy agenda the

269.text:
climatistas has been revealed to be completely
absurd. And I'll walk you through that here

274.text:
in a moment. But there's a corollary to that.
As a thought experiment, even if catastrophic

281.text:
human-caused climate change turned out to
be true, environmentalists are the last people

286.text:
we would want to put in charge of dealing
with the problem. Full stop.

291.text:
When I'm in a mischievous mood, I did this
at Boulder a lot; I would say to environmentalists,

295.text:
I said, "Look, let's just quit arguing about
the science. It's really tedious. But, only

300.text:
conservatives could fix this, you know." And
that was always fun.

305.text:
The third funny thing that has happened is
something that no one predicted. There's been

310.text:
some talk about it today at lunch and other
presentations, and that's the revival of the

316.text:
oil ... gas ... energy sector through the
technological revolution of directional drilling

322.text:
and "rock massaging"--that's what I call fracking,
"rock massaging." No one saw this coming.

329.text:
As recently as ten years ago, all the official
forecasts, including of a lot of the energy

333.text:
companies--ExxonMobil's annual forecast, British
Petroleum--they all predicted continuing declines

338.text:
in gas production in the United States, and
by the year 2020, not far off from now, the

343.text:
United States was predicted to be importing
20% of its natural gas from, guess who?

349.text:
And now, that has all changed. And the important
thing is this: this all happened very quietly

355.text:
out in the private sector, as was explained
at lunch today, and if our political class

360.text:
in Washington, in the media, had known this
was going on, they surely would have done

365.text:
something to stop it. And that's what they're
trying to do now, of course, but there's too

369.text:
late, there's too much momentum. Aren't markets
and innovation wonderful?

372.text:
So, let's take these in order. First, about
the warming stopping. Between roughly 1978

378.text:
and 1998, a 20 year period, the catastrophic
global warming scenario seemed to have some

385.text:
evidence on its side. During that roughly
two decade period, the global average temperature

390.text:
rose suddenly and sharply by about four tenths
of a degree Celsius, and conveniently that

396.text:
was right in line with what a lot of the newfangled
computer climate models predicted. But then,

401.text:
as we say, the funny thing happened: it suddenly
stopped. Even though greenhouse gases kept

406.text:
rising the atmosphere at a steady rate. Now,
at first, the pause, as it's come to be known,

413.text:
could be plausibly attributed to random year
over year variation, what ordinary people

418.text:
call, "weather," or, what the scientists call,
a, basically, chaotic climate system, that

427.text:
they will quickly acknowledge they don't fully
understand, and a couple other one-off events

431.text:
like the Mount Pinatubo eruption in 1992,
which changed some things, but now we're going

437.text:
on 18 years ... really, almost 20 years depending
on how you treat 1998, which I won't do now,

444.text:
but we're going on 17, 18, up to 20 years
without any warming, and all the models are

448.text:
starting to be falsified. The actual temperature
record is now falling below 95% of the climate

456.text:
model temperature forecast. In other words,
95% of the projections are proved to be wrong.

461.text:
Because there isn't just one, by the way,
if you get into this misery.

465.text:
There's several dozen different computer climate
models generating a different temperature

469.text:
forecast. And the record of the last two decades
is now falling below the lowest forecast for

474.text:
the future. All but about one or two of the
models are basically still in the ... If this

479.text:
goes on for another five to ten years, 100%
of the models will be shown to be wrong. Because

484.text:
the basic theory says we should be continuing
to increase about two-tenths of a degree per

489.text:
decade as long as greenhouse gases are going
up at the rate they are, and it's not happening.

493.text:
It is becoming the biggest embarrassment for
the scientific consensus since Piltdown Man.

501.text:
You know, somebody today asked Ken Greene
about, or made reference to the email scandals

507.text:
of the East Anglia climate unit in 2009. There's
one of those emails from climatologist Kevin

514.text:
Trenberth, he's one of the deep-dish climate
alarmists at Boulder, and he said, in one

518.text:
of those emails, and I'll quote him here,
he said it was a "travesty" that climate scientists

524.text:
could not explain the pause. And that's five
years ago, now, and we're still pausing.

530.text:
They've been scrambling ever since to offer
a whole series of explanations, and the intergovernmental

539.text:
panel on climate change, the U.N.'s I.P.C.C.,
as Ken mentioned today, they're doing their

543.text:
best to paper this all over and twist and
shout and do everything they can to try and

550.text:
cover up the fact that their scheme is failing.
I think maybe my favorite moment in the media

558.text:
... there's only a couple people in the media
who cover this honestly ... one of them I

561.text:
should give fair credit to is Andy Revkin
at the New York Times, who's pretty environmentalist

566.text:
in sympathies but pretty much plays this issue
straight. Good for him. The other is The Economist

571.text:
magazine, which is otherwise very much within
the so-called consensus, and they wrote, back

576.text:
in March, quote, "If climate scientists were
credit rating agencies, climate sensitivity

584.text:
would be on negative watch." Good for The
Economist.

590.text:
Now, I'm a glutton for punishment, so ... this
is why Ken and I are friends, I guess. I read

597.text:
through a lot of the latest I.P.C.C. report
on climate science. It came out about a year

601.text:
ago. The science report is, you know, 1300
pages long or something. In particular, if

607.text:
you're a glutton, I recommend reading chapter
nine. It is called, "Evaluation of Climate

613.text:
Models." It's 218 pages long, 218 pages of
very small print, and, Ken said you can't

620.text:
quote it; actually, you can't even read it.
That's not quite true; it takes a long time

627.text:
to figure out what's going on. You know, these
days, if the complaint made of people like

633.text:
me and Ken if we say the word uncertain or
uncertainty it's bad faith. A chapter on computer

638.text:
climate models from the U.N., it has the word
uncertain or uncertainty 173 times in 218

646.text:
pages, and it uses the term error or errors
192 times. I'll describe a couple of these

654.text:
errors and uncertainties for you. What they
try to persuade you is we keep twisting the

660.text:
knobs on these computer models long enough
we can get it to match up with what's happened.

665.text:
Except you keep going and you realize they
can't even do that. And they admit these things

670.text:
very grudgingly and talk about how certain
areas of essential knowledge of how the climate

677.text:
system works continue to really elude our
grasp. In particular, clouds. Clouds and water

683.text:
vapor. That's really important to the story.
So, let me quote one quotable part, which

689.text:
goes like this: "There remain," this is a
quote, now, "There remain significant errors

694.text:
on the model simulation of clouds." Next sentence.
"It is very likely that these errors contribute

701.text:
significantly to the uncertainties and estimates
of cloud feedbacks, and, consequently, in

707.text:
the climate change projections." And, if you
really read it carefully and ... ten times

714.text:
... you realize that they admit that it's
possible that clouds ... they admit that clouds

717.text:
could cancel out most of the forcing effect
of greenhouse gases. This is what people like

722.text:
Richard Lindzen have been saying for a long
time.

726.text:
Now, I'm not just a glutton for reading these
reports when they come out. I went to the

731.text:
trouble of finding some of the drafts leading
up to it. You can get people to leak these

735.text:
things to you. And one of the last drafts
before the final report came out had this

742.text:
sentence in it. In that same chapter nine,
which I thought was quite curious. Here's

745.text:
the quote: "The ability of a climate model
to make future climate projections cannot

751.text:
be directly evaluated." Let that sink in for
a minute. We can't even evaluate our models.

760.text:
That sentence was dropped from the final report.
I'm sure someone said, hey, wait a minute,

763.text:
we can't say that. Instead, after a lot of
mumbley-mouth stuff about, you know, why the

770.text:
pause is happening and we're still confident
that we want to keep playing with our knobs,

774.text:
this sentence appeared, instead. This one's
even better, actually, when you think about

779.text:
it. Quote: "These projections were not intended
to be predictions over the short time scales

785.text:
for which observations are available to date."
Translation: pay no attention to our models

793.text:
behind the curtain. Just trust our judgment
that the end is near.

798.text:
You know, the great social scientist James
Q. Wilson used to say that social scientists

804.text:
should quit trying to predict the future because
they can't even predict the past. I think

812.text:
the climate science community might well heed
that advice.

816.text:
Where is the missing heat if you just want
to go from the orthodox climate theory? Most

820.text:
of the climatistas say it's going into the
deep ocean. And while that's a plausible theory,

826.text:
we have very little data to substantiate it,
and some data that's coming in recently suggests

830.text:
that it's not happening. And we have even
less understanding about how that might play

835.text:
out in the future. Other explanations for
the pause include unusual western Pacific

842.text:
wind patterns--I'm not making this up--aerosols,
which means, you know, a higher level of particulates

847.text:
in the atmosphere, and, my favorite, increased
solar variation.

853.text:
There's this thing up in the sky called the
sun. You may have seen it. And, what's strange

859.text:
is, an awful lot of people, I mean, not just
ordinary citizens who wonder about this, but

863.text:
scientists, even, would say, you know, what
about variations in solar radiation and sun

867.text:
spots and the climate science community, as
always, says, no, and their official models,

871.text:
if you read them, say it's a very tiny factor
in any variation in the climate, and so, for

876.text:
them now to say solar variation is driving
the pause, that's interesting, isn't it? How

881.text:
convenient.
We're up now to something like 57 possible

885.text:
explanations for the pause. I think they're
pulling that off a ketchup bottle. Right?

891.text:
Now, the pause and the admittedly persistent
limitations and errors of the computer climate

897.text:
models resemble in my mind the kind of anomalies
that the philosopher and historian Thomas

904.text:
Kuhn famously explained should constitute
a crisis for a dominant scientific theory.

911.text:
And while the climatistas refuse to acknowledge
it, this crisis is causing some serious second

917.text:
thoughts about the basic question of climate
sensitivity. In other words ... Ken gave a

921.text:
short primer on this afternoon, if you were
here. It's true that greenhouse gases hurry

925.text:
the temperature a little bit, and the climate
sensitivity models have always said, and they've

929.text:
always been rigged to say, it's going to do
a lot! And there are more and more studies

933.text:
published in the peer reviewed scientific
journals saying, know what? We have been systematically

940.text:
overestimating climate sensitivity. It's much,
much lower than we've been led to believe,

945.text:
and ... really, what this comes to is, this
is a non-problem. Or not the kind of problem

951.text:
we've been told about. But instead of confronting
the fact that their cause has floundered mostly

955.text:
of its own dead weight, the climatistas have
ratcheted up new levels of bad faith and grasping

962.text:
authoritarianism. That's the technical terms
for what they're doing, I think.

967.text:
The result of the latest catalog of exaggerated
claims and appalling clichés is, you know,

972.text:
it's endless, but the most egregious one is
one that I'm sure many of you have heard of

976.text:
or seen on T.V. It's the ubiquitous refrain
that 97% of all scientists believe in climate

983.text:
change. By the way, they even use that word;
believe, like it's an article of religious

987.text:
faith, which I think is also a curious thing.
And it's not just climate advocates. NASA,

992.text:
a federal government agency, says ... they
have a web page that says, that phrase, 97%

997.text:
of scientists believe in climate change. That's
our government speaking, now.

1002.text:
And, of course, the political suggestion behind
this is, if 97% of scientists believe in climate

1009.text:
change, then, therefore, they must all agree
with the environmentalist agenda to suppress

1014.text:
energy. So, where did this 97% figure come
from? When you explore its lineage, it turns

1021.text:
out to be about as convincing as a Chicago
election. No, you can't believe that, right?

1030.text:
... The most prominent form of it comes from
a paper by a professor in Australia named

1034.text:
John Cook at the University of Queensland,
and he published this paper in an obscure

1038.text:
journal, and it's just rocketed around and
it's become the big thing. And what this study

1042.text:
purported to do was review the abstracts of
11,000 climate science articles. Now, just

1048.text:
stop right there. It's important they say,
abstracts. No one's going to read 11,000 climate

1053.text:
articles.
Even a whole team of graduate students is

1055.text:
not going to read through 11,000 science articles.
So they read the abstracts, fair enough. The

1059.text:
abstract is always that one paragraph summary
at the head of any academic journal article.

1065.text:
Well, here's the abstract to the Cook paper,
which no one in the media seems to have the

1070.text:
wit to read for themselves. First sentence:
"We find that 66.4% of abstracts expressed

1080.text:
no position on anthropogenic global warming,
comma." I'll stop right there. Two thirds--66%--two

1087.text:
thirds of the papers express no opinion on
human-caused global warming. Let's keep going.

1095.text:
Thirty-two point six percent endorsed anthropogenic
global warming. Zero point seven percent rejected

1101.text:
it and 0.3% were uncertain. Okay.
So that means a third of those papers had

1106.text:
an opinion on human-caused global warming.
So, the next sentence says this: "Among abstracts

1114.text:
expressing a position on human-caused global
warming, 97.1% endorse the consensus positions

1120.text:
that humans are causing the warming."
Somehow this has become 97% of all scientists,

1127.text:
when it's 97% of a third of scientists. Or,
you might put it this way. You could just

1132.text:
as easily say, 66% of scientists publishing
in the field have expressed no firm opinion

1136.text:
on the matter. Or, still another way to think
about it is, this is the grandfather of all

1141.text:
simple-minded tautologies. Among all the scientists
who agree with the consensus, are all the

1146.text:
scientists who agree with the consensus. That
would be an adequate way of saying it.

1151.text:
Now, initially Professor Cook refused to share
the data with anybody else to how they've

1156.text:
been coded, and, what have they matched up.
That's always a bad sign right there, isn't

1160.text:
it? But, of course, in the modern world, with
things planted on internet databases, somebody

1165.text:
found the data. And, lo and behold, some of
the articles turned out to be not really about

1171.text:
climate science at all. One article that was
billed as a science article was about U.S.

1175.text:
media coverage of climate change issues. Strangely,
in those 11,000 papers, there's not a single

1182.text:
one from Richard Lindzen of M.I.T. He's the
most prominent skeptic in the climate science

1188.text:
community, who has been publishing on the
subject since 1961. None of his papers were

1193.text:
included, somehow. And yet, this phrase ... I
mean, you can't go anywhere now without seeing

1198.text:
it or, you know, get on the center for climate
progress without seeing that 97% of scientists

1203.text:
agree. Or believe in, right?
Well, it's clear that the climate establishment

1212.text:
has become as narrowly intolerant as any department
of gender studies on a college campus, and

1217.text:
for much the same reason. What this really
masks is a will to power, as I said at the

1221.text:
beginning. There's a pretty good new book
out on American environmentalism, called Climate

1226.text:
of Crisis, by Emory University historian Patrick
Allitt. It's not a bad book, I reviewed it

1231.text:
last week in the Weekly Standard, and he thinks
that the next generation of scientists, like

1238.text:
previous generational successions, will seek
to overturn the conventional wisdom of the

1243.text:
current community. I hope he's right about
that. Now, I understand the academic dynamic,

1247.text:
but I'm not so sure. I don't think it's like
history, where each generation of historians

1251.text:
likes to say the previous one was all wrong
about the American founding, or something,

1254.text:
right? I'm not sure it works that way in science.
I think he underestimates how deeply the environmental

1260.text:
movement is invested in the idea of catastrophic
climate change.

1265.text:
But, that leads me to the second funny thing
that happened on the way to global warming,

1271.text:
and that's the still incomplete realization
of the sheer absurdity of the climate policy

1275.text:
agenda. Now, global warming was always the
dream issue for environmentalists, because

1282.text:
it gave them license to commandeer the entire
energy sector of the entire world. And, as

1288.text:
energy is the master resource that enables
all other resource use, it's the ... I would

1293.text:
say, the platform for material human progress
itself. Getting control of energy is the commanding

1298.text:
height of human civilization. But, what they
have proposed is a transformation of the world's

1307.text:
energy system so sweeping and so unrealistic
that it would make King Canute blush with

1312.text:
embarrassment.
And, here, I'm going to have to walk you through

1315.text:
a few numbers. I tend not to like to try and
do numbers in a talk like this, because it

1319.text:
can be hard to follow. I didn't want to do
PowerPoint for the same reason as Ken, because

1322.text:
numbers on a screen are even worse, in some
ways, because you can't see em. So, I'm going

1326.text:
to try and stick with me on this, and I'll
make this as straightforward and comprehensible

1331.text:
as possible. But, you begin with this. The
target of climate policy orthodoxy is an 80%

1340.text:
percent reduction ... eight zero ... 80% reduction
in carbon dioxide emissions worldwide, not

1347.text:
just the United States, worldwide by the year
2050.

1351.text:
Eighty percent reduction by 2050. I call it
for shorthand the 80 by 50 target. No one

1359.text:
actually knew what this meant in practice
until I and a few other people got after it.

1365.text:
And ... you know, you throw out these large
... 80% of something, and, you know, six billion

1370.text:
tons of emissions. What does this all mean?
It's hard to know when you're throwing around

1373.text:
these ... my eyes glaze over numbers, right?
Well, here's how this works, and I'll translate

1379.text:
this into real terms for you.
The big round number you start with is that

1382.text:
... it's changed a little bit, but this is
good enough for our purposes, here. The figure

1389.text:
that the Department of Energy starts with
from a few years ago is ... The U.S... . we'll

1393.text:
just use the U.S. for now ... U.S. emitted
about six billion tons a year of carbon dioxide.

1400.text:
That's about 20 tons per capita. Twenty tons
for each of us. Now, 20 tons sounds like a

1406.text:
lot. One little fact that's fun is, each one
of us individually exhales about 800 pounds

1415.text:
a year of carbon dioxide, just from breathing.
So, you can see, a nice down payment on the

1420.text:
way to your 20 tons, just from breathing in
and out. So that's not really that much if

1424.text:
you think about it, then. Twenty tons. Now,
an 80% reduction ... actually 83% in the Waxman-Markey

1431.text:
Bill, but don't worry about that ... it takes
us down to about 1.1 billion tons. Or, if

1436.text:
you want to just keep it simple, we're going
from six billion, roughly, in round numbers,

1439.text:
to about one billion.
Now, the first threshold question I got curious

1445.text:
about was: when was the last time the United
States' carbon dioxide emissions were that

1451.text:
low? You can figure this out ... takes a little
bit of work; it's not that hard ... you got

1455.text:
to go through the historical data tables that
are available. And, the answer you come to

1460.text:
is that the U.S. last emitted a billion tons
of carbon dioxide around 1910. Maybe 1905.

1468.text:
That's another calculation someone else did
that's pretty good. In 1910 the U.S. had only

1473.text:
92 million people. If you do the math, that
meant we had about ten tons per capita emission.

1479.text:
So, about half of the level we are today,
with 92 million people. However, in the year

1485.text:
2050, if the census bureau is right, we're
going to have about 420 million people in

1489.text:
this country. What that means is, if we're
going to have to stay under a billion tons
